thread.title: 'It's normal to be mentally healthy and homosexual': Study challenges stigma
thread.title_full: 'It's normal to be mentally healthy and homosexual': Study challenges stigma

author: Adrienne Francis
title: 'It's normal to be mentally healthy and homosexual': Study challenges stigma
text:
Map: Canberra 2600 
Canberra professional Kylie Walker says discrimination and a lack of community awareness about homosexuality contributed to her mental health problems during adolescence, rather than her sexual orientation itself. 
Ms Walker hoped a new study from the Australian National University (ANU) about the main drivers of mental illness, with a strong examination of sexual orientation, would break down myths and stigma about homosexuality and depression. 
Ms Walker was a student at Canberra Girls Grammar in the late 1980s and early 1990s and said people who identified as gay or lesbian were not spoken about or visible. 
"I remember knowing since early puberty that I was attracted to women but I didn't really know what to do about it," she said. 
"I remember not wanting to be attracted to women and being disgusted by my attraction." 
Ms Walker said not being able to express who she was made her feel lonely, marginalised and like there was something wrong with her. 
"All of those things led to anxiety and depression," she said. 
Ms Walker also recalled the destructive impact of one of her school peers being publicly outed as a lesbian, against her wishes. 
"She had a really rough time, there were a lot of really nasty rumours, people called her names, she was terribly bullied which made it very clear to the rest of us that it wasn't okay," she said. 
Ms Walker said it was not until her 20s, while working as a journalist, that she was able to acknowledge her risk-taking behaviour and depression. 
"I was drinking too much and I was using drugs and I was not happy," she said. 
"I was suffering pretty full-on anxiety and there would be times when I was sitting in the corner unable to answer a telephone, unable to get myself out of the house and talk to people. 
"I kind of came to terms with it by saying to myself that I must be bi-sexual and therefore it is fine to be with men." 
Ms Walker went onto marry her then-partner and friend, a man, and have two children. 
But the relationship broke down when the children were aged one and three, and the couple have since divorced. 
Ms Walker said she came out as a lesbian in her 30s before meeting "the love of her life" Anita Dwyer four years ago. 
The couple became engaged last year and are waiting for same-sex marriage to become a legal possibility in Australia before they tie the knot. 
She has since learned that at least five of her school peers are lesbians. 
"If we had room at school to be able to say who we were then, a lot of us would not have struggled so much in our teens and 20s," she said. Negative social interactions 'major driver' of mental illness 
The ANU study found that negative social interactions were more likely to drive long-term mental health problems than an individual's sexual orientation. 
The research aimed to challenge the common perception that homosexual and bisexual people were at risk of poor mental health and suicide. 
Since the late 1990s the research team has tracked more than 5,000 adults from the ACT and Queanbeyan. 
"The risk that has often been associated with sexual orientation, or non-heterosexual orientation, is due to other risk factors which may be more predominant amongst [those] people," lead researcher Richard Burns said. 
"The presence of positive or negative social interactions and support were really big drivers in people's mental health outcomes." 
Common risk factors like sexual trauma, childhood trauma and smoking were also identified as posing more of a long-term mental health risk than non-heterosexual orientation. 
"There was very little risk for poor mental health amongst those with a homosexual orientation, particularly for those who remain stable and continue to identify as homosexual as they age," Dr Burns said. 
"In terms of those who identified as bisexual orientation, they did appear to have an increased risk of poor mental ill health, but we found that was being driven by other well-known risk factors for poor mental health." Study could break down myths around homosexuality Photo: Kylie Walker (right) and her partner Anita Dwyer met about four years ago. (Supplied) 
Ms Walker said a lot of systemic discrimination against LGBTI people was based on the premise of mental illness. 
"[Non-heterosexual orientation] was classified as a mental illness [in the past in the United States] and anything that we can do to say it is normal, and to be mentally healthy and be homosexual, is very important," she said. 
Ms Walker said the support of her family and friends played a critical role in helping her overcome depression. 
"The years since coming out have in many ways been the best in my life," she said. 
"Even if you don't have that support you can find that support elsewhere, there is the family you are born into and there is the family that you choose."
